reviewText:
This game is simply a blast to play. It feels like everytime you play, ridiculous plays happen, causing both teams to get hyped up. It's easy to learn the basics, but there is an insane skill cap meaning truly great players can run circles around you... so that means there's a ton you can get better at, so you can replay it endlessly. The game is quick to load, so you can hop right in and play. Games are fast but intense. There are unlockable items, but one item unlocks pretty much everytime you complete a match. There's light car customization (cosmetics only!), and honestly this is probably the weakest part of the game... it could be so much better, but it's enough to have fun with and provides a decent amount of uniqueness. There's some affordabale DLC for more personalization.

No real complaints about the game... you can sometimes get bad teammates, but you can always re-queue and get different people. It feels like the game is probably going to keep growing, and is only at its early stages of life.

It's highly advised to play with a controller... I haven't used keyboard and mouse, but very few people seem to... you can still do well with them, but the precision of a controller with steering and rolling your car is a huge advantage right off the bat.

reviewText: God damn. This is what a video game should be like. No rock paper scissor fight-is-over-before-it-begins, no levels to give you an unfair advantage, no foolproof win-most-of-the-time strategies, just a pure game of skill.\n\nThe game is easy to learn but hard to master. Controls are snappy and responsive, pings are usually low (and when they aren't, the compensation does magic), and playing in a team with strangers is usually pleasant, assuming they do their best to not bump into you. This game is the essence of what a pvp game should really be like.

reviewText:
Lots of fun from the first second - Starting out as a pretty chaotic game of hitting the ball as hard as possible in roughly the right direction, Rocket League changes as you do, quickly becoming a fast paced and very tactical game as you anticipate the balls (and other players) movement in an effort to land strong, accurate shots. Easy to get into, but with enough depth to provide a lot to learn and a lot of fun playtime.

Only downside is that if, like me, you find it easy to get angry at losing, or playing badly, this game will drive (hah!) you crazy at times.

10/10 overall.

reviewText: About time to write a review for this game.  Should you buy it YES.  Can I tell you why?  Absolutely not.  Rocket League has that je ne sais quoi, the X factor, the perfect blend of addictive gameplay and arcade fun.  Top it all off with Psyonix adding things seemingly every month and keeping the game fresh with new modes, new maps, new cars, etc.  Even if you're not a sports fan, or a driving/racing fan...get this game.  If you don't love it I guarantee your money back(as long as you play less than 2 hours)

reviewText:
I can safely say that I have never enjoyed playing football this much in my entire life. Hell, I hate football in real life and I still love this game. Because guess what? Unlike real football, this game actually isn't boring.

Great, funny and addictive game. Worth every cent I spent on it. Buy it even for its full price, dont wait for sale - you wont regret it.

One warning though - buy it with some friends and play with them. If you are gonna play solo you are gonna have a really bad time since even on Silver ranks the average public Rocket League player has a brain capacity of mashed potato.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Let’s not waste energy exploring why soccer should replace its paper chain of squalid billionaires with cars, and accept it as fact. A fact which Rocket League proves with simple and immediate ease.

I’ve never played a game that needed a tutorial less. Association football, soccer, wendyball; whatever you want to call it, it’s that, but on wheels. Drive car at giant ball; hit ball into net; score points. Rocket League’s competitive core has existed for centuries, and this helps make a preposterous concept feel primal. This, in turn, is a laughable way of describing a game which would be called moto carball if it actually existed.

Like dry martinis and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ scribbled in an unattended notebooks, Rocket League is a celebration of simplicity. Driving is delicious. Cars ease around like butter in a heated pan, but always feel under your control. You accumulate boost by driving over markers on the arena floor and unleash it is a thunderous rush that fires you across, over and around the pitch. Because matches take place in smooth, enclosed spaces, you can drive up walls and across ceilings. Cars can also jump and dodge, both of which can be used defensively and offensively. The weight of the cars, as well as your ability to apply unruly boost to jumps, adds a pleasingly haphazard element; like athletic footballers leaping to header high balls, but with less shirt-pulling and zero chance of flattening a £2000 hairdo.

Cars ease around like butter in a heated pan, but always feel under your control.
Vehicles feel light and buzzy—somewhere between Micro Machines, and those swift, slidey remote controlled cars which only seem to appear on Christmas Day. This contrasts nicely with the fat, beefy bounce of the ball, which gormlessly invites impact like a punchable cousin. And that’s it. I feel almost guilty reducing a review to ‘ball’ and ‘car’, but there are only ever those two things in the field of play, and crucially, they both feel great. It’s helped by a crisp, intuitive camera. You can focus on the ball, effortlessly whizzing around with it always in view, or switch to the standard camera - very useful for rushing back to defend your goal, or smashing into other vehicles. There are no weapons, but certain markers fill your boost and let you obliterate other players. Mercifully, it’s the generous, instantly-respawning type of obliteration. Destruction is the only conspicuous deviation from clean business of driving around and scoring goals, but in most of the games I played it was a rarity—certainly never frequent enough to be irritating.

Destroying other vehicles is one of many actions which accumulates points; imagine Burnout, but with awards for skill not speed. You receive points for things like clearing the ball from your goal line, spectacular saves and overhead bicycle kicks—named so because the more literal ‘quadracycle wheel-nudge’ is a senseless stew of words. Giving everything a points value means it’s about more than scoring goals. The most valuable players I encountered were workmanlike wingers who selflessly chugged along the the flanks, crossing the ball for greedy goalhunters like me. It stops players from clustering in the same spots and reinforces the concept that Rocket League is a team game.



Except, of course, when it’s not, such as when you’re duelling against a single opponent. Alternatively, you can set teams of four against each other, in matches which become so frantic that they’re less like footy, more like a lost, confused beach ball bashed between bumper cars. Playlists of duels, doubles, standard 3v3 matches and the appropriately named Chaos 4v4 mode are all available online, with ranked playlists limited to duels, doubles and 3v3. There’s a reason why online play is the first option on the menu: Rocket League is designed to be played with actual people, and this is absolutely where it thrives. My experience was marvellously robust. I rarely had to wait long for a game, and if players dropped out mid-session they were immediately replaced by AI bots. Best of all, it’s refreshingly simple to get back into another game, so very little time is spent lingering in lobbies.

If playing online isn’t your thing, there are exhibition matches and full seasons you can solo. The length and difficulty can be altered, and while it doesn’t offer much in the way of depth—cars and football, remember?—I still found myself bonding with pretend teammates. Whether online or offline, playing games randomly unlocks new cars and upgrades. These range from simple things like fresh coats of paint and shiny wheels, to pointy hats for your wizardmobile. Upgrades are purely cosmetic, but volume, variety and the promise of driving around with bubbles frothing from your exhaust should be enough to keep you coming back.

The offline modes do reveal the game’s minor inadequacies, however: team AI can be flaccid and unreliable, especially against tougher opponents, and the same simplicity which makes Rocket League immediately playable can cause things to get repetitive when played alone; a criticism that only becomes apparent precisely because it’s so damn addictive. It’s a simple thing done brilliantly well, kept interesting by the thrill of competition.

THE VERDICT
87/100
ROCKET LEAGUE
Rocket League is fast, fun and relentlessly enjoyable. The best football game without feet.

reviewText:
if you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding garlic bread recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients
4 cloves garlic, crushed
2 tablespoons butter
2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil
1 loaf crusty bread, split
3 tablespoons grated cheese, Parmigiano or Romano, optional
Chopped fresh parsley

Directions
Combine garlic, butter, and oil in a microwave safe dish or in a small saucepan. Heat garlic and butter and oil in microwave for 1 minute or in a small pot over moderate-low heat for 3 minutes.

Toast split bread under broiler. Remove bread when it is toasted golden brown in color. Brush bread liberally with garlic oil. Sprinkle with cheese, if using, and parsley. If you added cheese, return to broiler and brown 30 seconds. Cut into chunks and serve.

Recipe courtesy of your friendly neighborhood memer

reviewText:
I know this game doesn't really need the praise but as I don't often write reviews and when I do they're always for games I feel should never of been added in the first place I feel like it's a nice change to be able to write about a game as fresh as Rocket League is.

I'll start off by saying I was in the beta for RL but I never knew how much fun I would get out of it playing with friends, it was enjoyable back then playing alone but it's so much fun playing with friends.

The more people recommend this game and the bigger the game will get I think, I'm a big FPS gamer and I've played cs for most of the time I've owned a PC and I'm massively into eSports, any game with potential of that and I'm straight into looking into it, I've played most of the FPS Games out there, BF, CoD and even got into MOBAs. I mean it might already have some smaller leagues but I'm hoping this might be another game to take off into the world of eSports. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys that side of gaming or someone would just likes something to play while you feel in the mood for a change of pace, and also the casual PC gamer who just plays anything you're able to get your hands on. I can only imagine it's already got people buying it from all the big streamers playing it like LIRIK, summit, Soda and the rest.

Going back to the game I feel like the devs have done an amazing job with this game, the gameplay is solid, it's enjoyable for short term gameplay or hours of gameplay and it's cheap for a game in todays world where anything on Steam can cost up to £50 but you could say it's not a type A title, Gameplay is mostly easy, the basics are easy to lock down but when you attempt to learn the timings for rocket boosters, jumping off walls and other things you could spend days, weeks or maybe even months attempting to get them to a system you feel is reasonable.

The game has a decent setup for people, the FOV can be changed aswell as camera angles.. The only thing that annoys me personally is I use the talk button on my controller for mumble but everytime I set the button seems to reset so I have to keep doing the same change everytime I boot the game back up, I suppose there is a simple fix for it out there, I've read editing files or making the config read only is a temp fix.

In terms of how the game plays? Very smooth, I'm sadly one of the AMD gfx card owners and while some games are just poorly optimized for my card this is good. Controller support is also good and I recommend using one to play.

Overall this game is one of my favourites this year at just £15. People thinking of waiting for the sale if you have money to spare I would just buy it now, I honestly don't think you'll regret buying this game, I'm one of those people who normally wait and I was going too but the amount of gameplay I kept seeing on Twitch, I just decided just to buy it anyways and I'm glad I did.

reviewText:
9/10 - Final revision
This game is the successor to Psyonix's 2008 PS3 game titled 'Supersonic Acrobatic Rocket-Powered Battle-Cars' (SARPBC)
It's like soccer or hockey, with cars, and it's intense.
You can boost, double jump, flip, and fly by aiming your boost mid-air. You can drive on the walls and ceiling, or blow up other cars. Your objective is to hit a giant ball into the opposing team's goal. Whichever team scores the most, wins. There's an endless overtime for tied games.
It's really simple to pick up and has controller support(rebinding, too!), but it takes tons of practice to actually get good at it, and even then there's endless room for improvement. The skill ceiling is much higher than you'd expect. You'll still be getting better after a thousand hours.
There's ranked and non-ranked cross-platform multiplayer. Multiplayer matchmaking options include 1v1, 2v2, 3v3, 4v4.. You're able to search for all of them at once if you wish. You can also limit the matchmaking region to whichever is closest to you so you'll get a better ping. You're able to make private lobbies on dedicated servers to invite players from any platform, and modify the game's rules with mutators.
The game uses Unreal Engine 3, so it looks and runs great. You have plenty of options to improve your performance if you need to do so. You'd be fine running the game around ~40FPS anyway. There's a fair bit of vehicle customization with unlockables as well.
PC players have an option to disable cross-platform matchmaking. Unfortunately cross-platform parties only work in private games.
DLCs are just cars or cosmetics. All new maps are automatically downloaded free for everyone.
If you plan on playing competitively without a full team using mics, you're going to get frustrated. One incompetent teammate or a little miscommunication can easily cause a loss, and you'll see this often.
Sometimes it will show other players block the ball and hit it away, but then teleport the ball back on the path it would be on as if it were never blocked, throwing everyone off and usually resulting in a free goal.
It's addicting and populated, there's skill-based matchmaking, game-deciding lag, a little toxicity(because it's competitive), and plenty of questionable physics.
Your hitbox will sometimes(rarely) clip through the wall a little bit, causing you to hit something, bringing your car to a halt, as seen here[gfycat.com]. The game seems to stop you from turning as you're ascending the base of a wall as well, it can really screw up your shots if you're in a hurry.
New modes were added to the game; Snow Day(Hockey mode with a big puck) and Hoops(Basketball with big nets), as well as some very different, experimental maps under the Rocket Labs" playlist. Hoops is a very good mode that's nearly just as good as the standard mode
date: so expect a lot of play time!"

reviewText:
Fast paced football with rocket powered cars, super fun.

Pros
+ Nice, appealing graphics.
+ Low skill floor with a high skill ceiling. (Easy to learn, hard to master)
+ Cross platform play with PS4 users!
+ Choose from standard matchmaking or play ranked! Matchmaking from 1v1 to 4v4 (Ranked mode has 1v1 to 3v3)
+ Party up and jump into matchmaking with friends! (Private matches available too!)
+ Vehicle customisation, it even has hats!
+ Offline play season mode.
+ Leaderboards, replays and stats.
+ Level up, and unlock new titles.
+ Full text chat with mic support, and quick chat with premade messages!
+ Supports up to 60FPS (Capped, but can be unlocked for users who want more)
+ Servers for Europe, East US, West US and Oceania.

Cons
- Can not party up with PS4 users currently. (Devs are working on this)
- I've found that I play the game in short bursts, as the game can get a bit repetitive.

The game has multiple maps too, but they only make cosmetic changes, entirely debatable if this is a good thing or not.

reviewText:
FIFA with Rocket Cars.

Rocket League is one of those great ideas that may have found its way into little minigames embedded in larger games, but Psyonix finally decided to go ahead and make a full fledged experience dedicated to it. Essentially a soccer game where you drive a car to bump a giant soccer ball around, Rocket League has plenty of epic saves and amazing goals that keep you coming back for more. There is even a ranking system plus a competitive matchmaking mode for those who want to test their mettle against similarly skilled players.

Psyonix has also pledged to not introduce powerups or any changes to game balance, which is fantastic as all the cars handle the same essentially. I've heard rumors that some of the hitboxes and handling are slightly different between cars, but it is negligible at best. I've missed these kinds of games, where there are no silly perks" a la Call of Duty or car customization that can give you an edge in any way. It's just you
recommended: and the ball. The new DLC cars are mostly novelties and haven't given an edge to any particular model of car
